title: A Double-blind, Randomized, Parallel-group Multiple Dose Study on the Safety, Tolerability and Immunogenicity of ALZ-101 in Participants With Early Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The main purpose of this study is to evaluate safety, tolerability and immunogenicity of the vaccine ALZ-101 against Alzheimer's Disease. Patients diagnosed with early Alzheimer's will be included. The study have two parts. The Part A (including A1 and A2), includes four doses of ALZ-101 or corresponding placebo given over 16 weeks. Participant will be followed up to Week 30 in Part A1 and either continue in the extension part of the study, Part B, or complete Part A1. Participant not eligible to Part B will be followed up until Week 68 with no further dosing. Participant eligible for Part B will be treated with 2 doses of open-label ALZ-101, over 16 weeks and followed up during in total 68 weeks (Part A1 and B). Part A2 participants will be followed over 20 weeks.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is described as a vaccine (ALZ-101) given to provoke an immune response against Alzheimer's pathology. Public sources state ALZ-101 is an active (therapeutic) vaccine designed to stimulate antibodies specific to toxic soluble amyloid‑β oligomers (i.e., targeting Alzheimer’s pathology), which makes it a biologic disease‑targeting therapy rather than a general cognitive enhancer or symptom treatment. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act: Key trial details extracted from the description and sponsor materials — randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled multiple‑dose study in participants with early Alzheimer’s disease evaluating safety, tolerability and immunogenicity (four doses over ~16 weeks with an open‑label extension possible). The intervention is ALZ‑101 (vaccine) vs placebo, consistent with an active immunotherapy (biologic) approach. citeturn0search3turn0search7

Reflect: Classification check — because ALZ‑101 is an immunotherapy/vaccine designed to induce antibodies against a specific Alzheimer’s pathological species (Aβ oligomers), it fits the definition of a "Disease‑targeted biologic." There is no indication the trial is testing a small molecule, a symptomatic cognitive enhancer, or an intervention aimed only at neuropsychiatric symptoms, so 'Disease‑targeted biologic' is the appropriate category. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Web search sources (supporting evidence): Alzforum therapeutic entry summarizing ALZ‑101 as an oligomer‑specific active immunotherapy and Phase 1b data. citeturn0search0; Alzinova (sponsor) program page describing ALZ‑101 as an oligomer‑targeting vaccine and summarizing the Phase 1b study. citeturn0search3; Alzinova / PR Newswire company press releases describing the vaccine's target (Aβ oligomers), Phase 1b design and manufacturing/advancement news. citeturn0search1turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial drug ALZ-101 is described and documented as an active (therapeutic) vaccine designed to stimulate antibodies specifically against toxic soluble amyloid-β oligomers — i.e., it targets an amyloid-β species central to Alzheimer’s pathology. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: From the trial description and sponsor / literature sources, ALZ-101 is an oligomer-specific active immunotherapy (vaccine) given to provoke an anti-Aβ oligomer antibody response in early AD; the intervention therefore directly targets amyloid-β pathology rather than other pathways. Assigned CADRO category: A) Amyloid beta. citeturn0search3turn0search2

Reflect: This classification fits CADRO because the mechanism is disease-targeted immunotherapy against an Aβ species (toxic oligomers). There is no indication the intervention targets tau, inflammation primarily, synaptic plasticity, or multiple disparate pathways, so 'A) Amyloid beta' is the most specific CADRO match. If future data showed ALZ-101 had primary activity on another pathway, reassessment would be needed. citeturn0search0turn0search7

Supporting web sources used: ALZFORUM therapeutic entry summarizing ALZ-101 as an oligomer-specific active immunotherapy and Phase 1b data; Alzinova program and R&D pages describing ALZ-101 as an oligomer-targeting vaccine; company press releases and Phase 1b result summaries reporting safety, immunogenicity and anti-oligomer antibody responses. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search3turn0search5turn0search8
